definitions: place where someone stays temporarily, especially when traveling or away from home
act or process of providing or finding accommodation for someone
examples: The travelers found comfortable lodging at the mountain inn
Students searched for affordable lodging near the university campus
The company handled lodging arrangements for all conference attendees
Finding suitable lodging proved difficult during the festival season

definitions: room or space directly under the roof of a building, typically used for storage or converted to living space
high arcing trajectory of a ball or projectile in sports
building or compartment where pigeons are kept and bred
examples: The artist converted the warehouse loft into a studio
They stored old furniture in the dusty loft above the garage
The golfer used a wedge to loft the ball over the bunker
Her tennis serve had perfect loft and spin
Racing pigeons returned to their loft after the competition
The old man maintained a pigeon loft on the rooftop

definitions: section of trunk or large branch of a tree that has been cut for fuel or timber
official record of events, especially on a ship or aircraft
logarithm, especially when used in mathematical or computational contexts
examples: They split logs for the fireplace throughout winter
The cabin was built from sturdy pine logs
The captain made entries in the ship's log every day
Pilots must maintain accurate flight logs for safety
Students calculated the natural log of various numbers
The algorithm uses log transformation for data normalization

definitions: mathematical operation that determines the power to which a base number must be raised to produce a given value
examples: The logarithm of 100 to base 10 equals 2
Engineers use logarithms to calculate earthquake magnitude on the Richter scale

definitions: book in which details of a journey, experiment, or other systematic activity are recorded regularly
examples: The truck driver updated his logbook after each delivery
Scientists recorded all observations in the laboratory logbook

definitions: person who cuts down trees for timber as an occupation
device or software that automatically records data over time
examples: The logger worked in the forest from dawn until dusk
Experienced loggers know how to fell trees safely
The temperature logger recorded readings every hour
Network loggers track all system activities for security

definitions: large-headed sea turtle found in warm ocean waters worldwide
iron instrument with a ball at the end, heated for melting pitch
state of stubborn disagreement or deadlock, used in the phrase 'at loggerheads'
examples: The loggerhead turtle swam gracefully through the coral reef
Conservation efforts protect loggerhead nesting sites on beaches
Sailors heated the loggerhead to seal the ship's planks
The blacksmith kept several loggerheads near the forge
The two departments were at loggerheads over budget allocation
Negotiations reached loggerheads when neither side would compromise

definitions: commercial activity of cutting down trees for timber and transporting them
systematic recording of events, transactions, or measurements in computing or other fields
examples: Logging operations were suspended during the fire season
Sustainable logging practices help preserve forest ecosystems
The system's logging feature tracks all user activities
Error logging helps developers identify and fix problems

definitions: systematic method of reasoning based on principles of validity and inference
system of electronic circuits that process digital signals in computers
examples: Her argument followed clear logic from premise to conclusion
Students studied formal logic in their philosophy class
The computer's logic board needed replacement after the power surge
Digital logic gates form the basis of all modern processors

definitions: person who studies or is skilled in logic and logical reasoning
examples: The logician identified several fallacies in the politician's speech
Famous logicians like Aristotle shaped Western philosophy

definitions: graphic mark, emblem, or symbol used to identify a company, organization, or product
examples: The company redesigned its logo to appear more modern
Customers instantly recognized the brand by its distinctive logo

definitions: part of the body on both sides of the spine between the ribs and hipbones
cut of meat from this region of an animal, especially pork or beef
examples: The athlete wrapped a towel around his loins after the race
Traditional warriors wore protective gear around their loins
The chef prepared tender pork loin with herbs and garlic
Beef loin makes excellent steaks for grilling

definitions: single piece of cloth wrapped around the hips and groin area as minimal clothing
examples: Ancient Egyptian workers wore simple loincloths in the heat
The tribal warrior's traditional dress included a decorated loincloth

definitions: hard candy on the end of a stick that is licked or sucked
examples: The child enjoyed a cherry-flavored lollipop after the doctor visit
The candy store displayed colorful lollipops in the window

definitions: lollipop or ice lolly, especially in British English usage
informal British term for money
examples: Children queued for ice lollies on the hot summer day
She bought a strawberry lolly from the corner shop
He made loads of lolly from his business venture
They spent all their lolly on the holiday trip

definitions: person who prefers to be alone and avoids the company of others
examples: The mysterious loner lived in a cabin deep in the woods
Despite being a loner, she was content with her lifestyle

definitions: tall bow drawn by hand and used especially by medieval English archers
examples: English longbow archers were decisive at the Battle of Agincourt
The museum displayed a perfectly preserved medieval longbow

definitions: person who yearns or has a strong desire for something
examples: As a longer for adventure, she constantly planned new trips
The longer gazed wistfully at the distant mountains

definitions: long duration of life or existence, especially of a person, animal, or thing
examples: Regular exercise and healthy diet contribute to human longevity
The company's longevity in the market demonstrates its strong business model

definitions: breed of cattle with long horns, originally from Texas
beetle with very long antennae, also called longhorn beetle
examples: Texas longhorn cattle grazed on the vast ranch
The restaurant's logo featured a distinctive longhorn skull
The Asian longhorn beetle poses a threat to hardwood trees
Entomologists studied the longhorn beetle's wood-boring behavior

definitions: persistent yearning or desire, especially for something unattainable or distant
examples: She felt a deep longing for her childhood home
His longing for adventure led him to travel the world

definitions: angular distance of a place east or west of the prime meridian, measured in degrees
examples: The ship's navigator calculated their exact longitude using GPS
London sits at approximately zero degrees longitude

definitions: competitor, plan, or possibility considered very unlikely to succeed but still worth attempting
examples: Betting on that horse was a real longshot but it paid off
Getting the promotion seemed like a longshot given the competition

definitions: informal British term for a toilet or bathroom
historical card game popular in the 17th and 18th centuries
examples: She excused herself to visit the loo during dinner
The pub's loo was at the back of the building
They played loo at the gentleman's club every Thursday
The stakes in loo could become quite high

definitions: outward appearance or aspect of someone or something
instance or period of looking at or observing something
examples: She had a confident look that impressed the interviewers
The designer created a vintage look for the collection
Take a quick look at these documents before the meeting
His look of surprise told her everything she needed to know

definitions: action of searching for or trying to find something or someone
examples: The looking for a new apartment took several weeks
Her constant looking for perfection caused unnecessary stress

definitions: place from which to keep watch or view surroundings
person stationed to keep watch for danger or opportunities
examples: The fire lookout tower provided views of the entire forest
Ships used the crow's nest as a lookout position
The lookout spotted enemy ships on the horizon
Bank robbers posted a lookout outside during the heist

definitions: act of searching for information in a reference source or database
table or structure used for quick data retrieval in computing
examples: The dictionary lookup revealed the word's etymology
Quick lookup of customer records improved service time
The database uses a hash table for efficient lookup operations
Programmers optimized the lookup algorithm for faster performance

definitions: apparatus for weaving fabric by interlacing threads
indistinct threatening appearance of something approaching
examples: The antique loom still produced beautiful handwoven textiles
Workers operated industrial looms in the textile factory
Storm clouds began to loom on the horizon
Financial crisis loomed over the struggling company

definitions: diving waterbird with distinctive call found in northern regions
informal term for a silly or crazy person
examples: The haunting call of the loon echoed across the lake
Loons dive deep to catch fish beneath the surface
He acted like a complete loon at the party last night
Don't be such a loon, that plan will never work

definitions: informal spelling variant of loony, meaning a crazy or silly person
examples: The old looney down the street talks to imaginary friends
Stop acting like a looney and be serious for once

definitions: informal term for someone considered silly, eccentric, or mentally unstable
examples: The conspiracy theorist sounded like a complete loony
She's a bit loony but harmless and quite entertaining

definitions: shape produced by a curve that bends around and crosses itself
programming construct that repeats a block of code
section of film, music, or video that repeats continuously
examples: She tied the rope in a secure loop around the post
The roller coaster featured several thrilling loops
The for loop executed the code ten times
Programmers must avoid creating infinite loops
The DJ created a seamless loop of the bass line
The animation plays in a continuous loop on the screen

definitions: caterpillar that moves by arching its body into loops, also called inchworm
device or software that creates or plays audio or video loops
examples: The looper caterpillar inched along the branch
Gardeners control looper populations to protect crops
Musicians use a looper pedal to layer guitar tracks
The video looper displayed advertisements continuously

definitions: ambiguity or inadequacy in law or rules that allows circumvention
narrow opening in a wall for shooting or observation
examples: Tax lawyers found a loophole that saved their client millions
The contract's loophole allowed them to cancel without penalty
Medieval archers shot arrows through loopholes in castle walls
The fortress had numerous loopholes for defense

definitions: action of creating or moving in loops or repeated cycles
motion or path that curves back on itself
examples: The looping of the audio track created a hypnotic effect
Constant looping through the same code caused the program to crash
The bird's looping flight pattern helped it catch insects
The airplane performed spectacular looping maneuvers at the airshow

definitions: action or process of making something less tight, strict, or firmly fixed
examples: The loosening of the bolt caused the wheel to wobble
Economic loosening of regulations encouraged business growth

definitions: goods stolen during war, rioting, or from a place
informal term for money or valuable items obtained from any source
examples: Pirates divided the loot from the captured merchant ship
Police recovered the loot from the bank robbery
The kids compared their Halloween loot after trick-or-treating
She showed off her shopping loot from the sales

definitions: stealing of goods during war, riot, or natural disaster when law enforcement is absent
examples: Looting broke out after the earthquake destroyed the city
The army was accused of looting villages during the conflict

definitions: way of running or moving with a long bounding stride
examples: The wolf moved in an easy lope across the meadow
She broke into a comfortable lope along the trail

definitions: man of noble rank or high office, especially in British peerage
title used for God or Jesus Christ in Christian contexts
person who has authority, control, or power over others
examples: The lord owned vast estates in the countryside
Lord Wellington received honors for his military service
Believers gathered to worship the Lord in prayer
The Lord's Prayer is recited in many Christian services
He acted like the lord of the manor with his employees
The drug lord controlled trafficking in the region

definitions: authority, power, or position of a lord
formal title used when addressing a lord or judge
territory under the jurisdiction of a lord
examples: His lordship over the region lasted three decades
The lordship came with both privileges and responsibilities
Your Lordship, the court awaits your decision
His Lordship will see you in his chambers now
The lordship included several villages and farmlands
Medieval lordships often changed hands through marriage

definitions: body of traditions and knowledge on a subject maintained by a particular group
examples: Celtic lore includes stories of fairies and ancient heroes
Maritime lore warns sailors about various ocean dangers

definitions: large motor vehicle for transporting goods, called truck in American English
examples: The lorry delivered construction materials to the building site
Heavy lorries are restricted from using this narrow road

definitions: person or team that loses a game, contest, or battle
person who is generally unsuccessful or perceived as inadequate
examples: The loser of the match congratulated the winner graciously
There were no real losers in this friendly competition
Don't be such a loser, believe in yourself
He felt like a loser after failing the exam again

definitions: things or people that have been misplaced or cannot be found
state or condition of being wasted or unable to be recovered
examples: The lost and found department collected dozens of items daily
Among the lost were several valuable paintings
She mourned her lost youth and missed opportunities
The data represented lost productivity due to system failures

definitions: thick liquid preparation applied to skin for medicinal or cosmetic purposes
examples: She applied sunscreen lotion before going to the beach
The dermatologist prescribed a medicated lotion for the rash

definitions: form of gambling involving random drawing of numbers for prizes
process of selecting something by random chance rather than choice
examples: She won millions in the state lottery last week
Lottery tickets sell quickly when jackpots grow large
Getting into that school felt like winning a lottery
The visa lottery selected applicants randomly each year

definitions: game of chance similar to bingo using numbered balls drawn randomly
examples: They play lotto every week hoping to win big
The lotto drawing happens every Saturday evening

definitions: electroacoustic device that converts electrical signals into sound loud enough to be heard at a distance
examples: The announcement echoed through loudspeakers across the stadium
Portable loudspeakers provided music for the outdoor party
